title: Turning a Korean skincare trend into $630 million (Hero Cosmetics' Ju Rhyu) | Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: So I tried to launch it. I had a name.
Uh I had sourced the manufacturer. Um
you know I had the packaging and then I
just I just took I checked out. You guys
came? Yeah. I mean it's a it's a lot
it's a lot of commit commitment. I sheld
the idea. It took years for J Ryu to
work up the courage to launch Hero
Cosmetics and its signature acne
fighting product, the Mighty Patch. Soon
after she faced another big decision.
Should the company take on outside
investors? They were already profitable,
but what could they unlock with even
more
resources? The answer, a whole new level
of scale. We went from just like
nickeling and dimming everything. We had
to do it on the cheap. But once we put a
little money into the company, we were
like, you know what? This is this is now
an investment. This week on the show,
Hero Cosmetics co-founder Jrew Ryu takes
us inside each critical inflection point
along her extraordinary scale journey.
From the first product sold on Amazon to
getting on target shelves to exiting the
company after it hit $100 million in
sales.
This is Masters of
Scale. I'm Jeff Berman, your host. After
a rapid rise in the skincare space, Drew
Ryu sold Hero Cosmetics in 2022 for
million. Before we get her insights
about scaling and selling a business,
let's hear how she finally found the
courage to leave her steady corporate
job and become an entrepreneur. Welcome
to Masters of Scale. Yeah, thanks for
having me. I've been really excited to
have this conversation because I have
three teenagers, so I'm deeply familiar
with your products. Um, but before we
get to um, Hero Cosmetics and Pimple
Patches and uh, all sorts of other
interesting things, I'm curious about
your entrepreneurial roots, you come
from an immigrant family. Um, talk about
what it was like growing up uh, and and
where your entrepreneurial spirit came
from. I think it comes from my dad. My
dad is an entrepreneur. So, he uh, we
moved from Korea when I was three. This
was Yeah. in the 80s. and he actually
moved to Seattle as an expat. So he was
working for a big crane company and then
he moved uh the family to Seattle as an
expat and then just sort of saw the
writing on the wall for himself as a
kind of salary man I guess at this uh
big Korean company and then he decided
to leave and start his own business. So
he's in the the logging industry. He's a
log broker and you know just growing up
with that influence in my life and
seeing how he worked from home and he
was able to control his schedule and um
and he was able to fit work into his
life. I think those are all things that
I you know I grew up with and then
wanted for myself. And a lot of um kids
who grow up in families like that will
go in another direction because there's
a lot of uncertainty with an
entrepreneur parent. um uh and some lean
really into it. Um it almost feels like
you went in both directions. So you
didn't become an entrepreneur right
away. It's not like you dropped out of
college to start a company. Um will you
take us through a bit of your journey
leading up to becoming an entrepreneur?
So I had a career in in uh brand
marketing. Had an internship at Craft
Foods Manderly. Worked on the Planters
brand and uh back to nature and then
went to American Express. So I worked
for these big companies just sort of you
know getting the experience getting
getting established. Um but inside I
always like had the entrepreneurial
drive. So these a lot of times like
these big companies I would just get
frustrated because they would move slow
or I had all these ideas that just I
couldn't get um I couldn't get anywhere.
And so the drive was always there even
though you know I I had more of a
classic corporate career. Did did you
did you think about like could I become
an entrepreneur? could I work at one of
these big companies and and what Yeah,
that's I actually called that's what I
called myself. I called myself uh an
entrepreneur because at Craft Foods for
example like I loved working on the back
to nature brand. It was smaller. It was
maybe like a $30 million business. It
was a lot more entrepreneurial. I loved
new product innovation. Like I loved
ideiating and finding the white space
and really learning about um consumer
needs so that you know we could we could
meet them with new products. So that was
really fun and and just being part of
that whole journey I really enjoyed. So
I always gravitated towards new
businesses, new products, uh like the
new thing sort of. So many big companies
struggle with innovation, right? Um
whether it's because they're disrupting
their own business or they're just, you
know, you have to do 47 turns of a
budget deck before anyone will be
willing to approve your budget. Um what
what did you learn about what works in
moving innovation forward in big
companies while you were working at
places like Craft Dynamics?
It takes it, you know what, it takes a
lot of support from the top actually.
And um I mean, I'm sure we'll get to
this, but so my company, Hero Cosmetics,
we got acquired by uh a company called
Church and Dwight, and they are a a big
company uh not unlike, you know, the
Proctor and Gambles or the the Unilver
of the world, but um I've seen them move
really fast. And so I've seen them move
really fast, especially with our
international expansion. But that, you
know, I think the reason why they were
able to move so fast is it it was a
priority at the top. So it was sort of,
you know, all hands on deck. This is the
number one priority. We have to get this
into, you know, 50 countries in two
years or whatever. That's when I think
ideas really got pushed through. And so
it really does have to be embraced, I
think, at high levels. Yeah. I mean,
it's it's sort of a trope, but for a
reason that you get what you measure and
you get what you incentivize. Okay. So
let's go back. So um you go from Craft,
you're at AMX. Um, I think you then went
back to Korea. I went to Korea. What led
you back to Korea? So, uh, I worked as
an expat at Samsung. Samsung in Korea, I
mean, I think we all know it as an
electronics company, but in Korea, they
have many, many different branches of,
uh, this ginormous conglomerate. So, uh,
I worked for the financial services arm.
It was a big move. Um, I had never spent
a lot of time. I mean, the most amount
of time I spent in Korea was probably
like a month every summer. Um, and so, I
mean, it was not without risk. The big
question actually was, if I go, how do I
come back or, you know, would I be stuck
there forever? I don't really know. Um,
just because your relationships and your
your Yeah. Like, and is that experience
going to be desirable for American
companies? And it's hard to interview
when you're not living in the country.
Um, and so I mean I had a big like pros
and cons list and sort of, you know,
weighted all the factors and stuff and
and at the end of the day it was sort of
like why not, you know, why not? Um, I
was pretty confident that uh it would
give me good experience and I could
somehow figure out if I wanted to come
back a way to come back. Um, and so
yeah, so I took the I took the risk.
What did you learn in Korea?
Oh gosh. Um, I learned a lot
about like corporate culture there. Um,
just societal culture. I learned a lot
about myself, too. So, I'm, you know,
I'm Korean-American. I moved to the US
when I was three. But when I'm when I'm
in Korea, I feel so American. I really
like the the cultural gap is really big.
How does how does that show up?
I mean it's um even in communication
like I have an accent I have an American
accent when I speak Korean. It's
um just you know I think American
society and American culture is a lot
more about the individual and in Korea
it's more about the family unit or the
community like you're you know part of a
bigger um community that that you need
to worry about. Um, I think the role of
women is different, too. So, I think in
the US,
um, I mean, it's changing in Korea, but
I think like traditional roles for women
in Korea tend to be a lot more common
still. So, yeah, there I mean a lot of
big differences. Gotcha. And so, so
you're you're at Samsung again, you're
sort of on this trajectory with these
bigger companies. Um, is there an aha
moment? Is there an epiphany where you
say I am I'm now at a place where I
really want to go do my own thing? What
what happens that leads you to launch
Hero?
You know I um I actually tried to launch
it before. So I lived in Korea from 2012
to
2014 and maybe yeah after like 6 to 8
months of living there. That's I did
notice the acne patches back then. So
people were wearing them in public like
to the office and you know you go out to
a cafe and you just see them on people.
And this is a good moment just to
explain what the acne patches are for
for our audience who don't know. So the
acne patch is um it's a patch made out
of something called hydrocoloid.
Hydrocoloid is technically a wound
dressing. And so the way that it works
is a it creates um more of a moist
environment because when the skin is dry
it it doesn't heal as well. It has to be
a moist it should have a moist
environment for it to heal better. The
other thing is um the hydrocoloid it's
um it pulls moisture out. Oh, the
hydrocoloid this wound dressing you can
actually apply it to a pimple and when
you do it absorbs out the inflammatory
pus and it creates that sort of seal
over so you're not like touching and
picking and uh and it just really became
popularized in in Korea. Yeah. And so I
mean I'm old enough to remember when we
hit our acne. We didn't want people to
see our acne. It wasn't part of it. But
what you were seeing is effectively
these these little band-aids, right,
with with an acne solution on them and
it's almost almost becomes fashion. Is
that is that what you were seeing or in
Korea? I did not see that. But um there
are brands here in the US that have made
it a fashion statement. So you know
brands like Starface or others where you
know and here in LA I see it all over
just you know young people wearing the
little yellow stars on their faces. So,
I mean, it's interesting how the
conversation has really changed over the
years. And so, what you were seeing in
Korea back in 2012, 2014 range was, oh,
here's an acne solution. It's not yet
fashion. It's not yet a style thing, but
people are not embarrassed to have
something on their face covering up acne
and curing it. And and that was where
sort of the the coin dropped for you
that there's an opportunity here. Well,
I used it myself and I mean it was I
mean that was my like trans
transformative moment where like when I
peeled the patch off and it just got all
that gunk from my pimple. My pimple
literally was flattened overnight and it
just worked better than anything I had
used before and I just I kept asking
myself like why is this not available in
the US? It should be available in the
US. And so what was the answer? Why
wasn't available in the US? I mean it
just sometimes
ideas take you know an entrepreneur to
uh see the opportunity and bring it
over. I mean, um, I saw signs of it sort
of coming over, um, because there were
Korean brands that were selling in the
US and people really liked their acne
patches or um, on Reddit, I saw a lot of
people saying, "Oh, you know, I'm my
sister is going to Korea, so I'm asking
her to buy me all these boxes of these
acne patches." And so, I saw the the
demand and I saw uh, some early Korean
brands, you know, seeing some early
success with it. This was back in Yeah.
probably
2015ish, but there was no one that
really owned the category. Right. Right.
Um and so um what what what happens cuz
you don't launch the company until 2017.
So what happens between 2015 and 2017?
Yeah. Are you in product development?
Are you or have you shel the idea
because you want to do something else?
What what what took that time? Uh so I
tried to launch it. I had a name. uh I
had sourced the manufacturer um you know
I had the
packaging and so this was probably like
2014 2015 and then it came time to place
that first PO which was like 10,000
units and I don't know however many tens
of thousands of dollars and then I just
I just to I chickenened out. You got
scared? Yeah. I mean it's a it's a lot
it's a lot of commit commitment. I I was
by myself and I I remember I had some um
co-workers and friends in Korea at the
time and I just I kept I kept talking it
up to them like oh you know we could do
this and I really think this is a big
opportunity and um I don't know I just
couldn't really get anyone else sort of
on board um and then and then I moved
back to the US and I just I sheld the
idea. what happens where you're able to
to restart the entrepreneurial process
and launch her for me it was finding
co-founders and um you know there are a
lot of solo founders out there and I I
respect them a lot because having been
through it having been through the whole
process it can be a very lonely
difficult journey and I realized yeah I
think for me I I'd rather have
co-founders because it's it's actually
more fun and I mean especially the first
time like you don't know what you're
doing and it's just it's nice to have
other people to talk to and bounce ideas
off of. So, so really I mean the idea
was still there. Um I had shelved it
let's say 2015 uh two years passed 2017
and so one of my co-founders um we have
dinner and I tell him like oh my gosh
like someone needs to do this I think
it's such a great idea. He was like I'll
do it with you and he he was a friend
from before. How did you know him? So he
was a colleague turned into a friend. So
him and his brother who his brother um
is also a co-founder. It was the three
of us. They had a digital agency and
that digital agency um uh I had hired
and so I was a client an ad agency. Uh
they were a digital agency where they
did ads, they built Shopify websites,
they built apps, anything digital they
they really did. So I was her client and
in that capacity we had experience
working together and then we became
friends and um and you know they had
been running this agency for like seven
years and I think they were also ready
for a different different project or a
new challenge and then so Dwight uh who
I had dinner with he was really
interested in in uh the Amazon
marketplace and being an Amazon seller
and you know you know I had this idea
and I thought it would be really great
on Amazon and so that's kind of what
kicked it off. And so it's it's a big
decision to start a company with with
one person, much less two people who
happen to be related to each other. Um h
how did you was it just instinct? How
did you get to a point of saying great
this is the right partnership. This is
what I want to do. These are the people
with whom I want to do it. This is where
I feel very lucky because I did not
consider any of that but ended up
working out. And I I mean I know there
are a lot of like founder divorces. I've
seen them and they're very difficult.
They can be super messy. Yeah. Yeah. And
I mean, thank God we never went through
that. But um in hindsight, in hindsight,
actually, the reasons why it worked out,
I actually think three, if you have, um
a co-founding team of three, it's
actually great because I remember and I
remember someone told me like, "Oh,
three is one too many." But I think it's
great because if there's always a
tiebreaker. So if two people, you know,
don't agree on something, I think
there's always a third person who can
kind of, you know, um, uh, tip it over
to one side. Um, and in retrospect, I
think we we had really complimentary
skill sets. So I knew this category, had
more of a marketing background, I had
that corporate experience, um, had some
finance experience. And then one
co-founder, he he's a he's a technical
engineer. So anything related to like um
DDC, Amazon, operations, it was great
for him. And then the third, Andy, he's
a creative guy. So anything sort of like
design, packaging, um like all that was
um was his responsibility. We didn't
always agree, but I think we always had
a willingness to like talk things out.
And then there was always a tiebreaker
to kind of make help make the decision.
And so the three of you decide you're
going to do this together. What's what's
the vision for the company?
You know, we didn't in the beginning, we
did not have like grand visions of like,
oh my gosh, we're going to build this
like huge company and it's going to be,
you know, this big and we're going to
conquer the world. It was very, we were
very practical. It was um uh there's
this there's this product out there. Uh
it it does really well in Korea. There's
early demand in the US. We think it's
going to do well in the US. So, let's
just start with one product and let's
test it out. So, we tested it out on
Amazon. What was the first product? It
was the Mighty Patch 36 count. We priced
it at $12.99. Uh, it's still the OG,
like the classic, the original. And, uh,
yeah, we put it on Amazon. We were like,
let's see what happens. And, and really,
I mean, it took off. And then and then
what does taking off look like at that
time? So one of the things that we did
that um I I tell people to do and I
would do again is you have to define
what is
success. So you know we came out with we
came out with like different scenarios.
We said um what is you know you hit it
out of the ballpark and it's a home run.
What what is that? Is it a million
dollars in a year? Is it more? like does
it mean do you have to be profitable? Um
and what is failing? So, you know, when
do you say okay this is not working out?
We had a theory, a thesis, but it's not
it's not turning out as we thought. Um
and then what's sort of like the middle
ground? And when you're in that middle
ground, then what do you do? Because
it's it's not a home run, but you're not
really failing. And so, you know, what
do you decide to do? Uh,
and you know, I think I think I can't
remember the exact like metrics, but I
think success for was for us was
something like half a million dollars in
the first year and we're making money.
That would be like success. And then
failing was, you know, this is just
going to take way too much more money.
We're doing maybe like I don't know
$100,000 and unprofitable and it's just
going to be a slog. And that middle
point was probably like some somewhere
in the middle like let's say it's like
250 and you break even and I think what
we decided was we're just going to fold.
Um so so basically for us it was like
it's going to be the home run or we're
just not we're going to move on to other
things. So the idea was you know test
put it out there and kind of fail fast.
Yep. Um and so I don't think any any of
us wanted to be like 10 years in you
know it's a grind. we're not really
getting anywhere. Just we just we just
didn't we wanted to avoid that
situation. Did you quit your job to go
do this full-time or was this a side
hustle first? It was a side hustle
first. Okay. So, and and so to get that
first order, you you find your
manufacturing, you you source your
materials, you figure out how to get it
to the US and get it get it to Amazon so
they can ship it for you. How much did
it cost? How much did you have to raise?
Did you self-unded?
And how how much did you put into the
business among the three of you at that
point?
So I think it was 50,000 initially. So
um that's what got us up and running.
But then and then we were growing really
fast. So we had to make loans to the
company just for cash flow. But we
bootstrapped until for the first three
years. As you're watching the sales
climb there, what's what's working for
you? How are people finding the product?
Like you don't have a big marketing
budget. No. So So h how are people
discovering the product? What were you
doing to get it out there? Uh we did
earned media really. Um so
um we seated a lot of micro influencers
you know asked them to post asked them
to talk about it just send them free
product and just gifting gifting gifting
as much as possible and then uh really
and then where we saw a lot of success
also was with press and I just remember
seeing our scale our sales skyrocket so
I was like there's something to this and
so initially we seated a lot of those
more um commerceoriented publications so
Buzzfeed had a lot of like the 50 top
products you need to buy today or um I
think the New York Times wire cutter is
also a good example that are more you
know they they'll do like um deep dive
product reviews or yeah they'll do like
the listicles and be like yeah 10 new
products out this month and they always
link to your um commerce website and so
yeah we did that for a good chunk of
time because we we saw the results we
saw the results okay so J you you're
you're on this three-year um initial
part of the journey where the business
is growing, you and your co-founders are
making loans to the business to to be
able to stay ahead with your purchase
orders and what have you.
Um, at what point did you say, gosh, we
really need more capital and we should
take on an outside investor.
We So, you know, we were a profitable
business um, starting in year one and it
was always a question like, do we raise
money? Should we raise money? Do we do
it now? Then we we seriously started to
think about it. That was in year three.
So that was in 2020.
Great year to to be Oh yeah. Well, our
term sheets were due the week in March
when the lockdown started. Wow. So it it
I mean that was a disaster. The raise
didn't happen. Um but fortunately we
didn't need the money, right? Uh so we
were okay. But um well why before why
had you decided that was the time
setting co aside and what the craziness
that happened that year um what as a
profitable company that's growing why
did you say now's the time to raise
capital it it was more about needing the
strategic guidance so we we were kind of
on this rocket ship you know trajectory
and we you know we're firsttime
entrepreneurs in this category and so
we're like we don't know what we're we
should get some um smart money uh around
us so they can help guide us and make
sure that we have a successful outcome.
So, it's really about the partner and
and less about the money. It really
transformed our business because when
you're growing really fast um that cash
flow sort of uh chase is always tricky
like you know you you get paid but then
you need to buy more inventory and just
the timing of it all can be really
tricky and then it can sort of impede
you from make making investments like
hiring investments because good people
they're expensive and um and and so you
know when we put the money into the
company I remember our mind shift
changed because we went from just like
nickeling and dimeming everything to
like photo shoots and mer like
everything we just we had to do it on
the cheap. But once we put a little
money into the company, we were like,
you know what, this is this is now an
investment. And so instead of like
nickeling and dimming and try to find um
affordable talent, I was like, I want
the best VP of marketing, I want the
best VP of sales. And so um so we were
able to invest in areas like people. So
that was really nice. What was the what
was the inflection point where you went
beyond Amazon? At one point it was like
100% of our um revenue then it became
like 90 and then maybe became 80. But I
remember I went to a conference and um
these bankers were talking about channel
diversification and they were saying the
ideal channel diversification is a third
retail, a third Amazon, a third DTOC. I
was like, "Oh, they're probably right."
Because of course relying on one
channel, you know, for most of your
business is always risky, right? This is
the PayPal problem back in the eBay
days. Yeah. Right. Yeah. And um and so
we I remember we tried really hard to
make DDC work. We're like we have to
grow DTOC to be more than whatever
percent of the business. It was a small
percentage of the business. Um and then
and then we have to get into retail.
Like those are going to be the three
pillars of this business. So so early
on, yeah, we tried to diversify and um
and you know got into Target. We were
exclusive at Target, grew very deeply
with them. Were you exclusive to Target
with the exception of Amazon because you
already sell or would you Okay.
So for retail, you're exclusive to
Target, correct? Okay. And and when
you're I presume flying to Minneapolis
and you're sitting with the Target
executives and having this conversation,
I mean there there are other retailers
who matter. There's one really big one
that matters. How do you make the
decision that we're we're willing to go
exclusive with you in in the retail
category? I I always thought Target had
a really great brand image. I thought
they had really smart merchandisers who
were merchandising like cool new hip
indie brands that you know these
challenger brands. You got to north of
100 million in sales right before before
you exited the company. So what what
were the next set of inflection points
where where that up to the right kind of
hockey stick curve is happening for you?
Uh building out the team was a big big
one. So, we I had touched upon it
before, but um I tell people when we
hired because you know when you're a
small company and you're bootstrapping
like you can't afford expensive talent
um and so what you tend to do is you
hire the interns, you hire the uh 22 or
23 year old just uh who just graduated.
Um and they're great because they're
hungry, but they they don't have a lot
of experience. So you tend to have to
coach them and train them and you know
kind of work really closely with them to
help develop them. But when we took on
the growth round, you know, we knew we
needed to level up talent. And so some
of the first hires were these VP levels,
like experienced people. And it changed
my life. Changed my life as a founder
because I didn't have to um have 10
one-on- ones with people anymore. um it
was now, you know, the VP of sales or
the VP of marketing. Um it was their
responsibility and their team and and we
hired people who So I I I always say
like I hired people who would tell me
what to do. I didn't want to tell them
what to do. So I wanted people who had
the experience, who were experts in
their fields, and I would just, you
know, I just let them go. Um and I
wanted them to tell me like, you know,
we should be doing this or you should be
doing that. Um, and you know, again,
it'll it'll it'll change your life. So,
um, as you're scaling and the the the
mighty patch is the hero product of Hero
Cosmetics, but at what point do you
start launching other product lines and
and what's your process for doing that?
How do you decide we're going to do this
or that or the other thing? Yeah, that's
one of the things that we definitely um
scaled up in the early years. It was
sort of just me kind of thinking about
like what made sense as we expanded our
product pipeline. Um, and then as we h
started hiring more of a team, we we had
a full-on process. It it became this
whole process of like identifying whites
space trends, listening to our
consumers, listening to the retail
partners, what do they want, what do
they need, and then then just like
things get whittleled down like a
funnel. So, so a ton of ideas come at
the top of the funnel. So, we're we're
now into 2022. The company's continuing
to grow. You're still profitable. You're
going north of hund00 million in
revenue.
um you know the the the future is
bright. There is all sorts of
opportunity ahead. Um you all decided to
sell the company. Why? Part of it was we
took on growth money. So we had outside
investors who they want their money back
with return. So um so we you know they
they all need to be paid. And actually I
mean even before that earlier on um
again I have two co-founders. they're
brothers. I'm not related to them. And
you know, just thinking long term, you
know, un a lot of times, unless it's a
family business, it's hard to have that
sort of continued legacy because, you
know, who do you pass it down to and
things like that. Uh so early on with
the three of us, we knew
ultimately we did want to go for an
exit. We always had that $und00 million
